children.name: when you do not care about sth because it is not important to you
not care
children.definition: /nɒt ˈkeəʳ/  if you don’t care about something, it isnotimportantto you:
examples: không quan tâm vì nó không quan trọng
▪ ‘What do you think I should do?’ ‘I don’t care. Do what you want.’
not care what/whether/if etc
▪ I like George, and I don’t care what anyone else thinks about him.
▪ I don’t care what my parents say - I am going to the party.
not care about
▪ She doesn’t care about anything except money.

children.name: couldn't care less
children.definition: couldn’t care less/ˌkʊdnt keəʳ ˈles/ informalto not careatallabout something:

children.name: chẳng quan tâm chút nào
examples: ▪ The politicians are making a big deal out of the issue, but most voters couldn’t care less.

children.name: couldn’t care less about
examples: ▪ Shelley couldn’t care less about what other people thought of her.

children.name: couldn’t care less whether/if
examples: ▪ To be perfectly honest with you, I couldn’t care less whether he comes or not.

children.name: who cares?
children.definition: /so what?/what do I care? /ˌhuː ˈkeəʳz, ˌsəʊ ˈwɒt, ˌwɒt duː ˈaɪ keəʳ/spokeninformalsay this when you do not care about something, because you do not think it is important at all: ai quan tâm? thì sao? sao phải quan tâm ?
examples: ▪ So your house isn’t perfectly clean. Who cares?
▪ ‘Phil was really angry when he heard what you had done.’ ‘So what? It’s none of his business.’
▪ ‘He says he’s depressed and really short of money.’ ‘What do I care? It’s his own fault.’

children.name: not give a damn
children.definition: /ˌnɒt gɪv ə ˈdæm/  spoken to not care at all about something - use this when you are very annoyed with someone or something: not give a damn about

children.name: không quan tâm
examples: ▪ You’re so selfish. You don’t give a damn about anyone except for yourself.

children.name: not give a damn what/who/why etc
examples: ▪ I don’t really give a damn what the press says.

children.name: be past caring
children.definition: /biː ˌpɑːst ˈkeərɪŋǁ-ˌpæst-/  to no longer care about something that you were worried about for a long time, because you realize that the situation cannot be changed:

children.name: không còn lo lắng hay quan tâm vì một điều gì đó trước đây đã từng
examples: ▪ I used to worry a lot about my weight when I was young, but now I’m past caring.
▪ The company wrote and apologized for their mistake, but by then Sarah was past caring.

children.name: for all I care
children.definition: /fər ˌɔːl ˈaɪ ˌkeəʳ/  spoken say this when you do not care at all what someone does or what happens to them, especially when you are annoyed with them:

children.name: không quan tâm những điều người khác làm biệt khi bị họ chọc tức
examples: ▪ I don’t want to hear any more about her. She can drop dead for all I care.

children.name: let him/her/them (do st)
children.definition: let him/her/them (do something)/ˌlet hɪm (ˈduː something )/ spoken say this when you do not care if someone does what they have threatened to do:
examples: không quan tâm những gì người khác đe dọa làm
▪ ‘Brenda says she’s going to quit unless we give her a raise.’ ‘Let her quit then. It’s not as if we can’t find another nanny.’
▪ ‘They’re threatening to disconnect the phone unless we pay the bill.’ ‘Let them!’

children.name: tough!
children.definition: /tʌf/ spoken informal say this when someone tells you about a problem they have and you do not have any sympathy for them, especially because you feel angry with them:
examples: 'Quên chuyện đó đi'
▪ ‘Mom, I don’t want to go to school today.’ ‘Tough! You’re going anyway.’
▪ ‘Can’t we stop? I’m hungry.’ ‘That’s tough. I told you to eat something before we left the house.’

children.name: minor
children.definition: small and not very likely to have an important effect - used especially about changes, problems, injuries, damage, or differences :
examples: I've made a few minor changes.
The driver suffered minor injuries.
These are just minor problems.

children.name: insignificant
children.definition: /not significant/ˌɪnsɪgˈnɪfɪkənt, nɒt sɪgˈnɪfɪkənt/  not important enough to worry about, especially because there are other problems that are much more serious: không đáng kể
examples: ▪ The level of radiation was considered ‘insignificant’ and not a danger to health.
▪ There is a slight difference in the way men and women are affected by the drug, but this is not really significant.
▪ After a week of negotiations, the differences between the two sides are now relatively insignificant.
▪ EU financiers say that recent problems on the US stock markets were not significant for Europe.

children.name: petty
children.definition: /ˈpeti/  something such as a problem, argument, or worry that is petty is so unimportant that it seems silly or selfish for someone to talk or worry about: nhỏ nhen, vụn vặt
examples: ▪ We started having arguments over petty little things.
▪ The meeting spent too much time on petty issues, and didn’t address the real problem.

children.name: trivial
children.definition: unimportant and not serious, and not worth worrying about or spending time or effort on: tầm thướng, nhỏ nhặt
examples: The issue of where the peace talks will be held may seem trivial, but to the participants it is very important.
No, I don’t think your question is trivial at all.
trivia[U] information or facts that are not important and have no real use or value:
The magazine was full of trivia and gossip.
I find that I can remember trivia such as old sports results, but I can’t remember the things that I really need to remember.

children.name: trivial problem/matter/complaint etc
examples: We were punished for the most trivial offences.
Her feelings for Simon seemedtrivial by comparison.
Why waste time watching trivial TV programs?

children.name: unimportant
children.definition: not important/ /nɒtɪmˈpɔːʳtənt, ˌʌnɪmˈpɔːʳtənt◂/  formal not likely to cause problems or to have an important effect on something: không quan trọng
examples: ▪ ‘I forgot to add the olive oil.’ ‘Don’t worry -- it’s not important.
▪ I don’t want to waste time arguing over unimportant details.
It is not important that you understand everything at this stage.
▪ Critics have dismissed his work as unimportant.

children.name: small
children.definition: not important and not likely to take long to deal with or correct: nhỏ
examples: ▪ Your essay’s very good -- there are just one or two small points I’d like to discuss.
▪ There were a couple of small things I wanted to talk to you about.
▪ We had a few small problems when we were putting the design together, but it works fine now.

children.name: be of no importance
children.definition: /biː əv ˌnəʊ ɪmˈpɔːʳtəns/  formal to not be important, and be unlikely to affect anything in a serious way: không nghiêm trọng, không quan trọng
examples: ▪ If you’re capable of doing the job, your age is of no importance.
▪ These are small details and probably of no importance.

children.name: small and not making much difference to sth
slight
children.definition: /slaɪt/  small and not very important or not very noticeable:
examples: ▪ There has been a slight change of plan.
▪ The doctor says there has been a slight improvement in her condition.
▪ He was a good friend - always available to help at the slightest sign of need.
not the slightestnone at all
▪ Tom? I haven’t the slightest idea where he is
.▪ US foreign policy at the time hadn’t made the slightest difference in the situation.

children.name: infinitesimal
children.definition: /ˌɪnfɪnɪˈtesəməl◂, ˌɪnfɪnəˈtesəməl◂/  an infinitesimal amount, risk etc is so small that it makes very little difference or is not worth worrying about:
examples: ▪ Even an infinitesimal change in temperature will be recorded by the equipment.
▪ I’d say the chances of your catching the disease are infinitesimal.

children.name: tiny
children.definition: /ˈtaɪni/  extremely small:
examples: ▪ I’ve made one or two tiny alterations, but otherwise the house is the same as when I bought it.
▪ There’s been a tiny decrease in the number of people out of work.

children.name: minor
children.definition: /ˈmaɪnəʳ/  not important enough or serious enough to worry about:
examples: ▪ She fell off her horse, but suffered only minor injuries.
▪ The contract seems fine, except for a few minor details.
▪ With one or two minor changes, the course is the same as last year.

children.name: small
children.definition: /smɔːl/
examples: ▪ I want to make a few small changes to the design.
▪ There is still one small problem that we haven’t dealt with.
▪ Government statistics showed a small drop in the annual rate of inflation.

children.name: minute
children.definition: /maɪˈnjuːtǁ-ˈnuːt/  a change or difference that is minute is so small that it is difficult to see it or notice any effects resulting from it:
examples: ▪ The equipment records minute changes in air pressure.

children.name: subsidiary
children.definition: /səbˈsɪdiəriǁ-dieri/ formala subsidiary idea, question, subject etc is less important than the main one but it is connected with it:

children.name: phụ ( ko quan trọng bằng cái chính được liên kết với nó )
examples: ▪ If you take the English literature course, you can do linguistics as a subsidiary subject.

children.name: subsidiary to
examples: The formulation of a lasting peace settlement was the main objective, and everything else was seen as subsidiary to it.

children.name: incidental
children.definition: /ˌɪnsɪˈdentl◂, ˌɪnsəˈdentl◂/ happeningorexistingin connection with or as a result of something else that is more important:

children.name: phụ ( đi kèm với cái chính )
examples: ▪ The Red Cross will provide money for food, housing, and incidental expenses.

children.name: incidental to
examples: ▪ The puzzles are fun, but are incidental to the plot of the book.

children.name: purely incidental
examples: ▪ The concert is just for fun, really. Any profit we make from it will be purely incidental.

children.name: of less importance
children.definition: be of secondary/minor/less etc importance/biː əv ˌsekəndəri ɪmˈpɔːʳtənsǁ-deri-/  to be not very important compared to other things:

children.name: quan trọng thứ yếu
examples: ▪ It’s the perfect job for him - the salary is of secondary importance.
▪ Police are increasingly regarding cannabis use as being of minor importance compared with other forms of crime.
▪ We must stop treating mental illness as being of less importance than physical disabilities.

children.name: secondary
children.definition: /ˈsekəndəriǁ-deri/  less important than the main subject, problem etc: thứ yếu
examples: ▪ The government sees unemployment as a secondary issue.
▪ The study found that women were often reduced to secondary roles in the workplace.

children.name: secondary to
examples: ▪ Tourism is secondary to oil revenues as a source of income.

children.name: marginal
children.definition: /ˈmɑːʳdʒɪnəl, ˈmɑːʳdʒənəl/  too small and unimportant to have any useful or noticeable effect:
examples: ▪ The difference between the two cars is marginal.

children.name: peripheral
children.definition: /pəˈrɪfərəl/ relatingto the main activity, question, or subject, but much less important than it:

children.name: ngoại vi, thứ yếu
examples: ▪ It is a society in which women’s rights and concerns are still treated as peripheral.
▪ Too much money is being spent on peripheral programs when our kids can’t read or do basic math.

children.name: peripheral to
examples: ▪ The romance was peripheral to the movie’s main plot.

children.name: side issue
children.definition: a subject or question that results from or is connected with the main one being considered, but is much less important: phụ , ngoài lề
examples: ▪ The meeting seemed to focus on side issues, without ever really addressing the main point.
▪ One of the side issues that arose was what to do with the old equipment when the new things arrived.

children.name: pale into insignificance
children.definition: if someone’s problems or achievements pale into insignificance when they are compared to something else, they are clearly much less important: không thấm vào đâu, có là gì
examples: ▪ Our difficulties pale into insignificance when compared to the problems of the homeless.

children.name: insignificant
children.definition: not important enough or powerful enough to worry about or treat seriously: không quan trọng
examples: ▪ The anti-war group was an insignificant minority within the party.
▪ The spies’ payroll included insignificant clerks and highly placed officials.

children.name: the little guy U
children.definition: the little guy especially American, informal a person or organization that is not important because they do not have any power or influence:

children.name: những cậu bé ( ám chỉ những người , tổ chức không có nhiều quyền lực, ảnh hưởng )
examples: ▪ He got rich trading illegally on the stock market, using the little guy’s money.
▪ When the big retailers open a store, the little guys lose business.

children.name: lightweight
children.definition: /ˈlaɪt-weɪt/  someone who is well-known, for example in politics or literature, but is not really respected or considered to be important:
examples: ▪ His books are tremendously popular, but most of the critics regard him as a lightweight.

children.name: political/intellectual/literary etc lightweight
examples: ▪ It would be dangerous to dismiss her as a political lightweight.

children.name: nobody
children.definition: a /ə ˈnəʊbədiǁ-bɑːdi/ informalsomeone who is considered to be unimportant because they are not famous, powerful, or rich:

children.name: chẳng là cái thá gì cả
examples: ▪ He went from being a nobody to being paid $2 million a year.
▪ I felt like a complete nobody when I lost my job.

children.name: not important
children.definition: /nɒt ɪmˈpɔːʳtənt/  không quan trọng
examples: ▪ He’s not really an important figure in the organization.
▪ Don’t worry about the critics. They’re not important - they just think they are.

children.name: nonentity
children.definition: /nɒˈnentɪti, nɒˈnentətiǁnɑː-/  someone who is not at all important, powerful, or interesting, and has no special qualities or skills: vô danh tiểu tốt

children.name: ▪ Next to him, the other dancers seemed like nonentities
examples: ▪ He packed his government with nonentities, who would never challenge his leadership.

children.name: small fry
children.definition: informal a person or group who has very little power or importance compared to other people or organizations: cá con
examples: ▪ Environmental groups are small fry against the power of the big multinationals.
▪ Only the small fry on the drugs scene got caught by the police.

children.name: what you say when sth is not important
it doesn’t matter
children.definition: /ɪt ˌdʌzənt ˈmætəʳ/spokensay this to tell someone that something is not important and will not cause any serious problems:
examples: không vấn đề gì đâu
▪ ‘We’ve missed the train.’ ‘It doesn’t matter - there’s another one in 10 minutes.’
it doesn’t matter if/whether/what etc
▪ It doesn’t matter if you’re a few minutes late. We’ll wait for you.
▪ It doesn’t matter what other people think. You should do what you think is best.

children.name: it makes no difference
children.definition: /it doesn’t make any difference/ɪt ˌmeɪks nəʊ ˈdɪfərəns, ɪt ˌdʌzənt meɪk eni ˈdɪfərəns/ say this when you think something is not important enough toaffectwhat happens or change what someone decides:
examples: không ảnh hưởng gì đâu ( ko ảnh hưởng đến việc gì sảy ra hay một quyết định nào đó )
▪ ‘Do you want cash or a cheque?’ ‘It doesn’t make any difference.’
▪ Even if she had known he was lying it would have made no difference.
▪ It doesn’t make any difference whether you use fresh berries or frozen ones.
it makes no difference/it doesn’t make any difference to somebody
▪ It makes no difference to me if you want to go.
it makes no difference/it doesn’t make any difference to something
▪ You can have a single room or a double -- it makes no difference to the price.

children.name: it’s not a big deal
children.definition: it’s no big deal / /ɪts ˌnəʊ bɪg ˈdiːl, ɪts ˌnɒt ə bɪg ˈdiːl/spokensay this when you do not think something isimportantorworrying, even though other people may think it is:

children.name: chẳng có gì ghê ghớm cả
examples: ▪ My leg’s a little sore, but it’s no big deal.
▪ Just copy your work onto a disk - it’s no big deal.
▪ She assumed he’d be furious, but the whole incident just wasn’t a big deal to him.

children.name: it’s nothing
children.definition: /ɪts ˈnʌθɪŋ/spokensay this when you think something is not important and you do not want other people to worry about it: không sao cả
examples: ▪ ‘Are you okay?’ ‘Yeah, it’s nothing.

children.name: ’▪ ‘Why do you want to speak to Danny? Is he in trouble again?’ ‘No, it’s nothing, really. We just want to ask a couple of questions.’
the background
children.definition: If someone or something is in , they are not the main point of attention
examples: _Her worries about her job havefaded intothe background since she learnt about her father's illness.

children.name: not be the end of the world
children.definition: informal

children.name: If something is not the end of the world, it will not cause very serious problems
examples: _I'm really hoping to win, but it won't be the end of the world if I don't.

children.name: little
children.definition: adjectiveUNIMPORTANT

children.name: fringe
children.definition: nounEDGE
examples: the outer or less important part of an area, group or activity
_the southern fringe of the city
_the radical fringes of the party
